lesson.name: Lesson 2.12: Solving Problems with Inequalities in Two Variables

page.title: 2.12.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn to use graphing technology to find the solution set of a linear inequality in two variables. You will also write linear inequalities to represent the constraints in situations and then use the representations (including the graphs of the solutions) to answer questions about the situations. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use graphing technology to find the solution to a two-variable inequality.
  • Connect the different representations and interpret them in terms of the situation, when given inequalities, graphs, and descriptions that represent the constraints in a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.12.1: Graphing Inequalities with Technology
  • 2.12.2: Solving Problems with Inequalities in Two Variables
  • 2.12.2: Self Check 
  • 2.12.3: Matching Representations of Inequalities 
  • 2.12.3: Self Check 
  • 2.12.4: Graphing Solutions to an Inequality

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.12.5: Practice
  • 2.12.6: Summary

page.title: 2.12.1: Graphing Inequalities with Technology
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Use graphing technology to graph the solution region of each inequality and sketch each graph. Adjust the graphing window as needed to show meaningful information.


1. \( y > x \)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:

\(y > x\)



2. \( y \geq x \)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:

\( y \geq x \)


3. \( y<\text-8 \)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:

\( y<\text-8 \)


4. \( \text-x + 8 \leq y \)


Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:

\( \text-x + 8 \leq y \)


5. \( y < 10x - 200 \)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:

\( y < 10x - 200 \)


6. \( 2x + 3y > 60 \)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:

 \( 2x + 3y > 60 \)

page.title: 2.12.2: Solving Problems with Inequalities in Two Variables
page.contents:
Activity

Here are three types of situations. Answer the questions about each situation.

Bank Accounts

1. A customer opens a checking account and a savings account at a bank. They will deposit a maximum of $600, some in the checking account and some in the savings account. (They might not deposit all of it and keep some of the money as cash.)

a. Write an inequality to describe the constraints. Specify what each variable represents.

Enter your answer here:

\(x+y\leq600\), where x represents the amount deposited in the checking account and y the amount deposited in the savings account.



b. Use graphing technology to graph the inequality. Sketch the solution region on the coordinate plane and label the axes.


Enter your answer here:


c. Name one solution to the inequality and explain what it represents in that situation.

Enter your answer here:

(500,100). $500 is deposited in the checking account and $100 in the savings account. 

The total is $600, which is the maximum amount the customer plans to deposit.



d. If the customer deposits $200 in their checking account, what can you say about the amount they deposit in their savings account?

Enter your answer here:

The customer deposits $400 or less in savings.


2. A customer opens a checking account and a savings account at a bank. The bank requires a minimum balance of $50 in the savings account. It does not matter how much money is kept in the checking account.

a. Write an inequality to describe the constraints. Specify what each variable represents.


Enter your answer here:

\(y\geq50\), where y is the balance in the savings account.


b. Use graphing technology to graph the inequality. Sketch the solution region on the coordinate plane and label the axes.


Enter your answer here:


c. Name one solution to the inequality and explain what it represents in that situation.

Enter your answer here:

75. The customer deposits $75 in savings, which is more than $50.


d. If the customer deposits no money in the checking account but is able to maintain both accounts without penalty, what can you say about the amount deposited in the savings account?

Enter your answer here:

The customer deposits at least $50 in the savings account.


Concert Tickets

1. Two kinds of tickets to an outdoor concert were sold: lawn tickets and seat tickets. Fewer than 400 tickets in total were sold.

a. Write an inequality to describe the constraints. Specify what each variable represents.

Enter your answer here:

\(L+S<400\), where L represents the number of lawn tickets and S represents the number of seat tickets.



b. Use graphing technology to graph the inequality. Sketch the solution region on the coordinate plane and label the axes.


Enter your answer here:


c. Name one solution to the inequality and explain what it represents in that situation.

Enter your answer here:

(100,200). 100 lawn tickets and 200 seat tickets were sold. The total is 300 tickets, which is fewer than 400.



d. If you know that exactly 100 lawn tickets were sold, what can you say about the number of seat tickets?

Enter your answer here:

Fewer than 300 seat tickets were sold.


2. Lawn tickets cost $30 each and seat tickets cost $50 each. The organizers made at least $14,000 from ticket sales.

a. Write an inequality to describe the constraints. Specify what each variable represents.

Enter your answer here:

\(30L+50S\geq14,000\), where L represents the number of lawn tickets and S represents the 

number of seat tickets.



b. Use graphing technology to graph the inequality. Sketch the solution region on the coordinate plane and label the axes.


Enter your answer here:


c. Name one solution to the inequality and explain what it represents in that situation.

Enter your answer here:

100 lawn tickets and 250 seat tickets. The ticket sales would be 15,500, which is more 

than 14,000.


d. If you know that exactly 200 seat tickets were sold, what can you say about the number of lawn tickets?

Enter your answer here:

At least 134 lawn tickets must be sold to make at least $14,000.


Advertising Packages

An advertising agency offers two packages for small businesses who need advertising services. A basic package includes only design services. A premium package includes design and promotion. The agency's goal is to sell at least 60 packages in total.

a. Write an inequality to describe the constraints. Specify what each variable represents.

Enter your answer here:

\(b+p\geq60\), where b represents the number of basic packages and p represents the number of premium packages.


b. Use graphing technology to graph the inequality. Sketch the solution region on the coordinate plane and label the axes.


Enter your answer here:


c. Name one solution to the inequality and explain what it represents in that situation.

Enter your answer here:

(50,30). 50 basic packages and 30 premium ones are sold. The total is 80, which is more than 60.


d. If the agency sells exactly 45 basic packages, what can you say about the number of premium packages it needs to sell to meet its goal?

Enter your answer here:

The agency needs to sell at least 15 premium packages to meet its goal.


2. The basic advertising package has a value of $1,000 and the premium package has a value of $2,500. The goal of the agency is to sell more than $60,000 worth of small-business advertising packages.

If you know that exactly 10 premium packages were sold, what can you say about the number of basic packages the agency needs to sell to meet its goal?

a. Write an inequality to describe the constraints. Specify what each variable represents.

Enter your answer here:

\(1,000b+2,500p>60,000\), where b represents the number of basic packages and p represents the number of premium packages.


b. Use graphing technology to graph the inequality. Sketch the solution region on the coordinate plane and label the axes.


Enter your answer here:


c. Name one solution to the inequality and explain what it represents in that situation.

Enter your answer here:

(10,30). 10 basic packages and 30 premium packages are sold. The total value is $85,000, which is more than $60,000.


d. If you know that exactly 10 premium packages were sold, what can you say about the number of basic packages the agency needs to sell to meet its goal?

Enter your answer here:

The agency needs to sell more than 35 basic packages.


Video: Solving Problems with Inequalities in Two Variables

Watch the following video to learn more about solving inequalities in two variables.





Extending Your Thinking

This activity will require a partner.

Without letting your partner see it, write an equation of a line so that both the x-intercept and the y-intercept are each between -3 and 3. Graph your equation on one of the coordinate systems.

Your Inequality


Your Partner's Inequality


2. Still without letting your partner see it, write an inequality for which your equation is the related equation. In other words, your line should be the boundary between solutions and non-solutions. Shade the solutions on your graph.

3. Take turns stating coordinates of points. Your partner will tell you whether your guess is a solution to their inequality. After each partner has stated a point, each may guess what the other's inequality is. If neither guesses correctly, play continues. Use the other coordinate system to keep track of your guesses.

page.title: 2.12.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Use graphing technology to solve the following problem.

Jacob charges $20 to mow a lawn in his neighborhood and $100 to paint a room.  

Which combination of jobs earns Jacob more than $1,000?

answer.answer_text: Jacob mows 10 lawns and paints 8 rooms.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Jacob wants to earn more than $1,000, but this combination earns exactly $1,000. The answer is Jacob mows 8 lawns and paints 10 rooms.

answer.answer_text: Jacob mows 8 lawns and paints 10 rooms.
answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: Jacob earns $160 for the 8 lawns and $1,000 for the 10 rooms, earning more than $1,000 total.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Jacob earns $750 for the 35 lawns and $100 for the 1 room, earning less than $1,000. The answer is Jacob mows 8 lawns and paints 10 rooms.

answer.answer_text: Jacob mows 5 lawns and paints 9 rooms.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Jacob wants to earn more than $1,000, but this combination earns exactly $1,000. The answer is Jacob mows 8 lawns and paints 10 rooms.

page.title: 2.12.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Graphing Linear Inequalities in Two Variables to Solve Applications

Many fields use linear inequalities to model a problem. While our examples may be about simple situations, they give us an opportunity to build our skills and to get a feel for how they might be used.

EXAMPLE 

Hilaria works two part time jobs in order to earn enough money to meet her obligations of at least $240 a week. Her job in food service pays $10 an hour and her tutoring job on campus pays $15 an hour. How many hours does Hilaria need to work at each job to earn at least $240? 

  1. Let  x  be the number of hours she works at the job in food service and let y be the number of hours she works tutoring. Write an inequality that would model this situation.
  2. Graph the inequality. 
  3. Find three ordered pairs  (x,y)  that would be solutions to the inequality. Then, explain what that means for Hilaria.

SOLUTION

We let x be the number of hours she works at the job in food service and let y be the number of hours she works tutoring. She earns $10 per hour at the job in food service and $15 an hour tutoring. At each job, the number of hours multiplied by the hourly wage will gives the amount earned at that job.


b. To graph the inequity, we put it in slope-intercept form.

\( \begin{eqnarray} 10x + 15y \geq 240 \\ 15y \geq -10x + 240 \\y \geq - \frac{2}{3}x + 16 \end{eqnarray} \)


c. From the graph, we see that the ordered pairs \( (15,10) \), \( (0,16) \), \( (24,0) \) represent three of infinitely many solutions. Check the values in the inequality.

For Hilaria, it means that to earn at least $240, she can work 15 hours tutoring and 10 hours at her fast-food job, earn all her money tutoring for 16 hours, or earn all her money while working 24 hours at the job in food service.

Try It: Graphing Linear Inequalities in Two Variables to Solve Applications

Elijah works two part time jobs. One at a grocery store that pays $10 an hour and the other is babysitting for $13 per hour. Between the two jobs, Elijah wants to earn at least $260 a week. How many hours does Elijah need to work at each job to earn at least $260? 


a. Let x be the number of hours he works at the grocery store and let y be the number of hours he works babysitting. Write an inequality that would model this situation. 

b. Graph the inequality. 

c. Find three ordered pairs (x, y) that would be solutions to the inequality. Then, explain what that means for Elijah .


Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to model the problem and solve:

a. \( 10x+13y≥260 \)

b.


c. Answers will vary. Sample answers: \( (20, 10) \), \( (15, 20) \), \( (10, 25) \); For each of these coordinate points, if Hugh worked \( x \) hours at the grocery store and \( y \) hours babysitting, he would earn at least $260.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.12.3: Matching Representations of Inequalities
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you a set of cards. Take turns with your partner to match a group of 4 cards that contain: a situation, an inequality that represents it, a graph that represents the solution region, and a solution written as a coordinate pair.

For each match that you find, explain to your partner how you know it's a match.

For each match that your partner finds, listen carefully to their explanation. If you disagree, discuss your thinking and work to reach an agreement.

Record your matches.


Group 1

  • situation: perimeter of a rectangle
  • inequality:
  • a solution:
  • sketch of graph:

Group 2

  • situation: jar of coins
  • inequality:
  • a solution:
  • sketch of graph:

Group 3

  • situation: honey and jam
  • inequality:
  • a solution:
  • sketch of graph:

Group 4

  • situation: a school trip
  • inequality:
  • a solution:
  • sketch of graph:


Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answers may vary, but some solutions include the following:

Group 1 - situation: perimeter of a rectangle          Group 2 - situation: jar of coins


  
Group 3 - situation: honey and jam                  Group 4 - situation: a school trip

page.title: 2.12.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Veronica works two part time jobs in order to earn enough money to meet her obligations of at least $280 a week. Her job at the day spa pays $10 an hour and her administrative assistant job on campus pays $17.50 an hour. 

Which of the following is a solution that allows Veronica to earn enough money?

answer.answer_text: 5 hours at the day spa and 10 hours as an administrative assistant
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: In this combination, Veronica earns $50 at the spa and $175 on campus, which is only $225 in total.. The answer is 5 hours at the day spa and 15 hours as an administrative assistant

answer.answer_text: 10 hours at the day spa and 10 hours as an administrative assistant
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: n this combination, Veronica earns $100 at the spa and $175 on campus, which is only $275 in total. The answer is 5 hours at the day spa and 15 hours as an administrative assistant

answer.answer_text: 15 hours at the day spa and 5 hours as an administrative assistant
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You may have mixed up the pay rates. Veronica earns $10 at the spa and $17.50 as an administrative assistant. She would not earn more than $280 with this choice. The answer is 5 hours at the day spa and 15 hours as an administrative assistant

answer.answer_text: 5 hours at the day spa and 15 hours as an administrative assistant
answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: This ordered pair falls within the region representing the solution set.

page.title: 2.12.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Connecting Representations of Inequalities 

In order to connect the constraints of a situation with an inequality, its graph, and possible solutions, we need a mastery of each representation.

EXAMPLE 

Anika sells her photographs at a booth at a street fair. Each small photo she displays costs her $4 and each large photo costs her $10. She doesn’t want to spend more than $200 on photos to display.

Let x be the number of small photos and y be the number of large photos that Anika displays.

We know that each small photo costs $4 to display and each large photo costs $10. We also know that she doesn’t want to spend more than $200.

The inequality that represents this situation is \(4x\;+\;10y\;\leq\;200\).

To be able to connect this inequality with possible solutions, translating it into a graph is an important step.

Try It: Connecting Representations of Inequalities 

Graph the linear inequality: \(4x\;+\;10y\;\leq\;200\)

Is it possible for Anika to display 15 small paintings and 15 large paintings and maintain her budget of $200?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to see what your graph should look like and check your work.



No; the ordered pair (15, 15) does not fall within the region representing the solution. Another way to verify this is by using the inequality. 

\( \begin{eqnarray} 4x + 10y ≤ 200 \\ 4(15) + 10(15) \leq 200 \\60 + 150 \leq 200\\210 \nleq 200 \end{eqnarray} \)

Since $210 is not less than $200, 15 small paintings and 15 large paintings does not stay with Anika’s budget of $200.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.12.4: Graphing Solutions to an Inequality
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A band is playing at an auditorium with floor seats and balcony seats. The band wants to sell the floor tickets for $15 each and balcony tickets for $12 each. They want to make at least $3,000 in ticket sales.

  1.  How much money will they collect for selling x floor tickets?
  2. How much money will they collect for selling y balcony tickets?
  3. Write an inequality whose solutions are the number of floor and balcony tickets sold if they make at least $3,000 in ticket sales.
  4. Use technology to graph the solutions to your inequality, and sketch the graph.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

1. \( 15x \)

2. \( 12y \)

3. \( 15x+12y \geq 3,\!000 \)

4. See graph.

page.title: 2.12.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. This year, students in the 9th grade are collecting dimes and quarters for a school fundraiser. They are trying to collect more money than the students who were in the 9th grade last year. The students in 9th grade last year collected $143.88.

Using d to represent the number of dimes collected and q to represent the number of quarters, which statement best represents this situation?

Correct!  \(0.25q + 0.1d >143.88\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(0.25q + 0.1d >143.88\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. Which inequality is represented by the graph?

Correct! \(4x − 2y <12\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(4x − 2y < 12\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 3-4, use the passage below to answer the questions:

A farmer is creating a budget for planting soybeans and wheat. Planting soybeans costs $200 per acre and planting wheat costs $500 per acre. He wants to spend no more than $100,000 planting soybeans and wheat.

3. Let s represent the number of acres of soybeans and w represent the number of acres of wheat. Which inequality describes the situation?

Correct! \(200s + 500w ≤ 100,000\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 200s + 500w ≤ 100,000. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. Which of the following ordered pairs is a solution to the inequality?

Correct! (250, 100)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

One possible correct answer is (250, 100). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 5-7, use the passage below to answer the questions:

Amira is ordering dried chili peppers and corn husks for her cooking class. Chili peppers cost $16.95 per pound and corn husks cost $6.49 per pound.

Amira spends less than $50 on d pounds of dried chili peppers and h pounds of corn husks.

Here is a graph that represents this situation.

Correct! \(16.95d + 6.49h\) < 50

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(16.95d + 6.49h < 50\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


6. Can Amira purchase 2 pounds of dried chili peppers and 4 pounds of corn husks and spend less than $50?

Correct! No She would be spending 16.95(2) + 6.49(4), or $59.86.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. She would be spending 16.95(2) + 6.49(4), or $59.86. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Can Amira purchase 1.5 pounds of dried chili peppers and 3 pounds of corn husks and spend less than $50?

Correct! Yes. She would be spending 16.95(1.5) + 6.49(3), or $44.90.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. She would be spending 16.95(1.5) + 6.49(3), or $44.90. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 8-10, use the passage below to answer the questions:

A beach store rents surfboards for $15 per hour and beach umbrellas for $10 per hour. The store wants to make at least $200 per day on renting beach equipment. Let s be the number of hours that a surfboard is rented and u be the number of hours an umbrella is rented.

  1. Which inequality represents this situation?

Correct! \(15s + 10u ≥ 200\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(15s + 10u ≥ 200\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


9. Can the beach store rent surfboards for 7 total hours and rent umbrellas for 9 total hours and reach their goal of making $200?

Correct! No.They would be making 15(7) + 10(9), or $195.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is No. They would be making 15(7) + 10(9), or $195. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


10. Can the beach store rent surfboards for 10 total hours and rent umbrellas for 4 total hours and reach their goal of making $200?

Correct! No.They would be making \(15(10) + 10(4)\), or \($190\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.12.2 and 2.12.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. They would be making 15(10) + 10(4), or $190. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.12.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use graphing technology to find the solution to a two-variable inequality.
  • Connect the different representations and interpret them in terms of the situation, when given inequalities, graphs, and descriptions that represent the constraints in a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.12.1: Graphing Inequalities with Technology
    • In this activity, you used graphing technology to graph simple linear inequalities in two variables. You practiced adjusting the graphing window until the solution regions become visible and give useful information.
  • 2.12.2: Solving Problems with Inequalities in Two Variables
    • In this activity, you integrated several ideas and skills from the past few lessons. You wrote inequalities in two variables to represent constraints in situations, used technology to graph the solutions, interpreted points in the solution regions, and used the inequalities and the graphs to answer contextual questions.
  • 2.12.2: Self Check 
  • 2.12.3: Matching Representations of Inequalities 
    • In this activity, you practiced interpreting inequalities in context and reasoning about your solutions graphically and numerically. This sorting and matching task gave you opportunities to analyze representations, statements, and structures closely and to make connections.
  • 2.12.3: Self Check 
  • 2.12.4: Graphing Solutions to an Inequality
    • In this activity, you used technology to graph the solutions to your inequality and determined which side of the boundary line to shade.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.12.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
